official-title.#text: To suspend the visa waiver program in order for the Comptroller General of the United States to assess the national security risks posed by the program, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Visa Waiver Program Suspension Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to review the program for national security risks.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Comptroller General of the United States

text.#text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the visa waiver program established under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is hereby suspended for 180 days in order for the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall not allow the admission of an alien under the visa waiver program until—

text.#text: Notwithstanding the time period under subsection (a), the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: reports on the results of the review described in
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Comptroller General of the United States

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Visa Waiver Program Suspension Act of 2014/s:3

text.#text: the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: certifies that the national security recommendations from the review are implemented; and

text.#text: the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: certifies that the national security recommendations have been met.
shall report to the appropriate congressional committees.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Comptroller General of the United States

text.#text: Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the
The report required under subsection (a) shall include, at a minimum, a consideration of the following:
The number of terrorists from each country admitted under the visa waiver program.
The potential national security risks currently posed by each country admitted under the visa waiver program.
The number of persons permitted to travel without a verified Electronic System for Travel Authorization approval.
The number of persons permitted to travel with a denied Electronic System for Travel Authorization.

Whether terrorist organizations or other third party groups that pose national security threats are paying the Electronic System for Travel Authorization fees for persons entering the United States through the visa waiver program.
The current visa overstay rate for each country participating in the visa waiver program.
The impact on the travel industry, if any, of requiring screening at U.S. consulates for visa waiver program countries.
The cost and feasibility of implementing the automated biometric entry-exit control system authorized under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 110 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996/s:110

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall remove from the visa waiver program any country that—

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: report determines poses a national security threat to the United States;

text.#text: the
exceeds the visa overstay threshold; and
the Secretary determines that continued participation in the visa waiver program jeopardizes or could jeopardize national security.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: policy memorandum dated November 14, 2013, is repealed, retroactively to November 14, 2013.
